overview_of_class: From its origin in the ancient world, the skeptical tradition has represented a radically different way of engaging in philosophy. In this course, we will trace its development?both as a type of argument and as a way of life?from ancient Greece through the Early Modern period, when it was transformed in light of scientific and religious controversies. Our focus will be directed primarily at the work of Sextus Empiricus, Cicero, Montaigne, Charron, Bayle, Descartes, and Hume.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: From its origin in the ancient world, the skeptical tradition has represented a radically different way of engaging in philosophy. In this course, we will trace its development?both as a type of argument and as a way of life?from ancient Greece through the Early Modern period, when it was transformed in light of scientific and religious controversies. Our focus will be directed primarily at the work of Sextus Empiricus, Cicero, Montaigne, Charron, Bayle, Descartes, and Hume.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn about the distinctive nature of skepticism, its role in shaping the philosophical tradition, and its implications for how we continue to think about knowledge, justification, evidence, reasons, and, more broadly, an ethical life.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Short paper, presentation, comments, long paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Required: Pierre Bayle, Historical and Critical Dictionary, Hackett 978-0872201033 Cicero, On Academic Scepticism, Hackett 978-0-87220-774-5 David Hume, A Treatise of Human Nature, OUP 9780198751724 David Hume, An Enquiry concerning Human Understanding, Hackett 978-0-87220-229-0 Montaigne, Apology for Raymond Sebond, Hackett 978-0-87220-679-3 Sextus Empiricus, Outlines of Scepticism, Cambridge 978-0521778091 Note: you can use other recent editions of these works, if you have them or can find them in the library.
